9.9.18  11:15 am   How do you decide on a key signature for a song? I don't have perfect pitch so all the key signatures sound the same to me. If it has vocals, I'm guessing it's your vocal range but what if it has no vocals? Do you look at something like the fingerings on a keyboard? 

     i haven't done a song without vocals in many years. but in that case it would be wherever i first came up with the idea. no sense in transposing anything. this is also true with underscoring music

9.9.18  11:13 am   Did jesus actually exist? Maybe not as the son of god born to a virgin mother who performed miracles and was resurrected and all that stuff.. but like, was there actually a flesh and blood human person that all the stories are based from?

     it's likely

     I've always been curious about if jesus or mohammed or moses or siddartha and all those people actually existed, like in a non-religious sense... and I'm curious if you maybe came across anything about this when you were doing your hotewig research?

     i think some of those might have better records than others, but i generally would assume they are all based on someone. then over centuries the legends grow and grow and then eventually get bought by disney and become immortalized for eternity

9.9.18  9:25 am   what did u do at xoxofest? was it a panel like at vidcon

     said hi, bye, ran a 24 minute video compilation, and then came back and took audience questions. directed by andy baio, but not screened. he gave me the option to screen the questions but we did not screen the questions. i am glad, it was fun, i found a pair of glasses left on stage, which was helpful to me in my quest

9.9.18  8:51 am   Advice for going back to school?

     that was 2 weeks, not a month

9.9.18  7:16 am   what is talent?

     the on-air radio person

9.9.18  6:56 am   Whats your favorite superpower at the moment?

     speed

9.9.18  6:08 am   could you describe your mastering process?

     listen to to the track and then listen to a professional modern pop song and then contemplate suicide for a while and then pick myself up and then try to fix some things, i guess

      which things (compression, multipression, eq automation, limiting) do you do, in what order?

     i'm still figuring out the system, i got a lot more detailed on the last 3 songs (except the most recent one) and then suddenly i decided to start doing them in 1/4 of the amount of time, so a lot of that has gone out the window, which is good because it makes you gravitate toward the most important things.

      are there any examples of you using an effect on the stereo out track?

     not usually but that could be useful

     one time i did a reverb freeze going into the bridge and man that was powerful.

     i recently learned to group things to aux's. i should have learned that much sooner but i learned it recently. it's very good for doing reverb, and automating reverb. automating reverb opens a whole new door to fun times

     any nifty tips on efficiency or making it sound so damn freakin crisp and wonderful? thanks

     one weird weird thing i noticed, i was mixing hallelujah for way way too long and feeling trapped and down about it, listening to 'new rules' side-by-side with it and just wanting to die over it, (by the way this was just days before i found out the loudness war is officially over. so now we don't have to worry about that which is huge huge news, but this was right before i realized that) anyway, i had done all this work on the mix for hallelujah, and it's also just a really dense and layered textural arrangement, etc, and whatever, and then i was poking around for reference songs (such as new rules and several other songs done by other people) and was generally freaking out about how much clearer everyone else's songs sounded but (i'm getting to the point of this, hold on) here's the surprise: i accidentally opened up one of my jazz jam sessions (like anything you would hear on the 'jazz' section of this site) and i was shocked to find out that that recording sounded so much more clear, sounded like it was mixed much much better, but as we all know it is not even mixed at all. those are instrumental jams where i lay down each instrument in 1 crazy take, bounce it out and call it a day. and the point is, i found out that that mix (which was no mix) had a lot more punch and clarity than this hallelujah mix which i had so tenderly spent so many long days on. the lesson was , ...... if you use a million instruments it is a real challenge to mix it out of sounding like mud. even if it's very tenderly layered and arranged instruments, the point is, if there are many instruments, they will clog up the mid range, like that troublesome 100-300 range. but if you use only 3 or 4 instruments, ..... it's just got automatic clarity. so that's something. so this works to my advantage now working under these crazy deadline schedules, because i simply don't have time to make as dense an arrangement, and it is therefore easier to mix. Another thing i learned, on the subject of working faster, is, ... work faster. you gravitate toward what matters. and it is so easy to lose your mind if you listen to that damn thing for too long. you'll just lose your mind ...... another way to get tips is watching a billion mixing tutorials and tips videos until you realize they are all starting to contradict each other, and then you forget it and do what you want

9.9.18  3:39 am   how do I ace history?

     ace the present, that way when it becomes history you have already aced it in advance

9.9.18  1:41 am   hey bill, I've been wanting to use your strategy of try out for a lot of opportunities you don't particularly want to get, so that way when one comes around you do want you'll be prepared. but I get so psyched out when I try to apply for things, like, what if I get this and I have to commit, or what if I half-ass the application and don't get it and feel rejected and get sad? it's stuff that runs into my mind so eventually I put the application away and miss the opportunity entirely. how do I stop getting psyched out about it?

     the only time you have worries like this is before doing the thing. these are the kinds of worries that no one has while they are actually doing the thing

     yes, and so much more

9.9.18  1:28 am   hurricanes are having a big impact on us

     that's their job

9.9.18  1:20 am   can I know your feelings and thoughts about the song 'hallelujah'

     there are many many songs called 'hallelujah', and one day i got so jealous of all of them that i wrote my own

9.9.18  1:18 am   I keep finding abstract desires and ideas beyond my reach but I have no way to create them and it makes me feel lost even though I've come so far already. how can I make these ideas a reality? 

     that's cool but try working the other way. go straight to your tool kit, whatever that may be (pencil/paper? sandbox? legos? whatever it is that you normally use and have available) and just start going crazy and having fun With the tools you already have. this is how you will start to bridge the known world and your imagined world. if you keep working at it from both sides, it will be fun on both sides for a long time and then one day you won't even believe it but you will actually start to see them start to coincide

9.9.18  1:05 am   does spotify decide what's labeled explicit, or is that the artist's job?

     the artist is supposed to decide, but if they don't label something 'explicit' that is later found to be 'explicit', i have heard there are serious consequences. i don't know what it is but i have to assume some sort of sexual violation from a high ranking member of the clergy

9.9.18  12:01 am   "Juhkental uses a surrealist way of writing song lyrics: first he just babbles, records the nonsense and then starts thinking what words these sounds resemble.[6] His lyrics are mostly in English. He believes that he is not a good enough poet to write lyrics in Estonian, but considers English to be so messy that lyrics written in it will seem less bad than they would in Estonian."

What is your opinion on this method for writing lyrics?

     seems legit

9.8.18  9:00 pm   For the last year and two months, I've been trying to make something I'm proud of but I keep failing and giving up. I was six months into my most recent project and it was basically finished, but I realized it wasn't good enough and I wasn't proud of it so I scrapped it.

     that was probably not smart. i'm assuming you didn't delete it, but if you did then i don't even know what to say

     Now all the ideas and inspiration have just vanished and I have no motivation to make anything, and I'm paralyzed by my own inability to do anything. I'm in that aimless purgatory of not making anything and I need to get out but there's no way out, because I have no more motivation. How do I stop wasting away in aimlessness?

     why would you 'scrap' something you already spent 6 months working on

9.8.18  6:32 pm   I think what the "deeper meaning" questioners are asking is if there is some extra context that, when given, explains the lyrics through a different light. Maybe they really mean "hidden meaning", and they're thinking of Radiohead or some other band who has sort of cryptic lyrics. So, do you have songs like that? Where the context for some or all of the lyrics are omitted?

     my job is to deliver the maximum possible amount of meaning/feeling to the listener. it doesn't seem wise to me to have extra meaning/feeling on hand and deliberately hide/withhold it from the listener
